headline: Qualcomm Aims to Build $4 Billion PC Chip Business
summary: Qualcomm is aiming to become a big player in personal-computer chips, setting a target of $4 billion of revenue from that business in about five years' time.  Qualcomm’s chips for laptops—a market where it competes with Intel and Apple—launched this summer.  The company gave its 2029 fiscal year target for the business at an investor day Tuesday in New York, alongside a $4 billion goal for industrial chips and $2 billion for chips that go into virtual reality headsets and other similar devices.

headline: Qualcomm Sets New Growth Targets, Showcasing Company’s Opportunity as On-Device AI Accelerates Demand for its Technologies
summary: NEW YORK, November 19, 2024--Qualcomm Incorporated (NASDAQ: QCOM), a connected computing leader, today outlined its significant opportunities for growth and diversification at its 2024 Investor Day. The company’s unique position at the edge is driving access to an expanded TAM of approximately $900 billion by 2030, with more than 50 billion cumulative connected edge device shipments expected from 2024 through 2030.

raw.headline: Qualcomm Sets New Growth Targets, Showcasing Company’s Opportunity as On-Device AI Accelerates Demand for its Technologies
raw.summary: NEW YORK, November 19, 2024--Qualcomm Incorporated (NASDAQ: QCOM), a connected computing leader, today outlined its significant opportunities for growth and diversification at its 2024 Investor Day. The company’s unique position at the edge is driving access to an expanded TAM of approximately $900 billion by 2030, with more than 50 billion cumulative connected edge device shipments expected from 2024 through 2030.

headline: Qualcomm 'positive' on Trump administration as it forecasts chip sales growth
summary: (Reuters) -Qualcomm said on Tuesday it was "positive" on President-elect Donald Trump's incoming administration and not concerned that proposed U.S. tariffs on China would dampen its business in the country from which it derives nearly half its revenue.  Qualcomm executives made the remarks at an investor event in New York during which the company forecast $22 billion in combined revenue over the next five years from laptops, cars and other products outside its current stronghold in smartphones, a sharp growth from its latest fiscal year.  During a question-and-answer session with analyst, Alex Rogers, who runs Qualcomm's technology licensing business, said the San Diego, California, company had a "great relationship" with Trump's previous administration, which blocked a hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm from rival Broadcom.

raw.headline: Qualcomm 'positive' on Trump administration as it forecasts chip sales growth
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Qualcomm said on Tuesday it was "positive" on President-elect Donald Trump's incoming administration and not concerned that proposed U.S. tariffs on China would dampen its business in the country from which it derives nearly half its revenue.  Qualcomm executives made the remarks at an investor event in New York during which the company forecast $22 billion in combined revenue over the next five years from laptops, cars and other products outside its current stronghold in smartphones, a sharp growth from its latest fiscal year.  During a question-and-answer session with analyst, Alex Rogers, who runs Qualcomm's technology licensing business, said the San Diego, California, company had a "great relationship" with Trump's previous administration, which blocked a hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm from rival Broadcom.

headline: Qualcomm Expects to Make $22 Billion by 2029 From Expansion Bid
summary: (Bloomberg) -- Qualcomm Inc., the world’s biggest seller of smartphone processors, is expecting its push into new markets to generate an additional $22 billion in annual revenue by fiscal 2029. headline: Qualcomm downgraded as Apple split and licensing woes loom
summary: Investing.com - President Capital Management downgraded Qualcomm Incorporated (NASDAQ:QCOM) stock, citing mounting challenges, including regulatory risks, Apple’s shift to self-developed 4G/5G modem chips, a slowdown in its licensing (QTL) business, and weakness in the AI PC segment.
